intro: Jacquemontia ovalifolia subsp. sandwicensis, commonly known as the Hawaiian moonflower, is a rare and endemic species native to the Hawaiian Islands. It is a flowering plant in the Convolvulaceae family, characterized by its heart-shaped leaves and showy, white, night-blooming flowers. The plant thrives in moist, shaded environments, typically found in mesic forests on the islands of Maui and Molokaʻi. It is listed as endangered due to habitat loss and invasive species, making conservation efforts crucial for its survival. Its unique ecological role and aesthetic value highlight the importance of preserving native Hawaiian flora.
